awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Synthesis, Structural Characterization and Electrochemical Studies of Framework Substituted Silicon, Germanium and Tin Clathrates
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Abstract:
The structural integrity of a crystalline material is an important property that can greatly influence its ability to be utilized in practical applications. For electrochemical energy storage devices, daily operation involves the electrochemical insertion and extraction of ions, which is often accompanied by larger structural transformations that may cause the material to collapse. Hence, the search for new electrode materials is necessary in order for future energy storage demands to be realized. Clathrates are a class of materials with cage-like structures that can naturally hold guest ions, a feature that may be exploited in energy storage applications. However, different features in the clathrate bonding arrangement may affect its mechanical integrity. Key objectives of this project are to understand the electrochemical characteristics of these materials, how the structure of the clathrate changes upon electrochemical insertion of guest ions, and the development of new synthetic routes to obtain clathrates. Results from this project enable new knowledge on the intricate relationships among the clathrates? structures and their physical properties, electrochemical characteristics, and structural stability.

Technical Abstract:
The objectives of this project are: (1) to investigate the electrochemical and structural properties of germanium and tin clathrates using first principles calculations and detailed structural characterization to understand the electrochemically obtained structures; and (2) to synthesize new clathrates containing lithium ions from novel precursors. The project uses a concerted approach combining the synthetic, structural and electrochemical characterization, and theoretical expertise of the investigators. The research enables a better understanding of the relationship between the clathrate structure and its physical properties, electrochemical characteristics, and phase stability. These achievements could lead to higher energy density lithium and sodium batteries. The studies also help to build up the predictive power of solid-state chemistry, establishing new ideas of why and how atoms assemble and form new compounds and structures with the desired electrochemical properties. Investigation of these materials involves a collaboration between two universities (Arizona State University and University of Delaware) and three different departments (materials science, chemistry, and physics), which exposes students to multidisciplinary research. Outreach and educational activities engaging students ranging from the middle school to undergraduate levels, with an emphasis on recruiting females into science and engineering and improving student learning and engagement in introductory undergraduate classes.

por.por_cntn:
Background and motivation: This research project was motivated by the need for a better understanding of the critical features of clathrates that result in structural stability when the materials are used in electrochemical systems. The group 14 elements Si, Ge, and Sn have received significant attention as high energy density anodes for Li-ion batteries due to their ability to alloy with large amounts of Li. The accompanying volume changes, as high as 300%, have been well studied and are correlated with either amorphization reactions or formation of alloys with drastically different structures from the initial form. We have been investigating the electrochemistry and structural properties of Si clathrate materials, which have cage-like structures composed of face-sharing Si20, Si24, and Si28 polyhedra made of strong sp3-covalent bonds. The working hypothesis was that the open framework structure can enable electrochemical insertion of guest ions into the clathrates through fundamentally different processes than what is observed in the group 14 elements with the simple diamond structure. This project sought to deepen our understanding of the relatively un-explored area of clathrate electrochemistry.

Results: The electrochemical properties of clathrates were virtually unknown prior to the initiation of our studies. We found that the type I clathrates displayed reversible, solid solution-like insertion of Li with redox-dependent characteristics distinct from those observed in diamond cubic Si, amorphous Si, and other Si compounds previously studied. No discernable changes in the local bonding and crystalline structure of the type I clathrates were observed by nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) or X-ray diffraction (XRD) after lithiation. We independently found that the type II Si clathrates became amorphous during reaction with Li and eventually recrystallized as the metastable Li15Si4 phase, similar to what is observed in diamond cubic Si.

The origin of the drastically different behavior between type I and type II clathrates is still not understood. Our initial hypothesis was that the Si28 cages present in the type II (but not in type I) structure were more susceptible to amorphization upon Li insertion due to their largest size. Our data showed that Li insertion into framework vacancies or Ba vacancies in the Si20 cages could stabilize the clathrate structure. The results showed that changes in the clathrate atomic structure and electronic structure upon lithiation were found to be highly dependent on the location of the Li and the nature of the guest atom orientation within the clathrate framework. Furthermore, it was shown to be energetically feasible for multiple guest atoms to reside in the Si24 cages.

In close collaboration with the ASU partners, we have further extended these studies to Ge clathrates, which contain larger cage volumes compared to the Si analogs. The preliminary data (not yet published) indicate other factors may be in play. Type I clathrates were prepared by one of Chan's Ph.D. students during a month-long research stay in Bobev's lab at UD. The samples were then electrochemically characterized at ASU. The preliminary results show a dependency of the clathrate composition on the resulting structural changes, with the Ba8AlδGe46-δ clathrate surprisingly undergoing amorphization, while theK8LiδGe46-δ clathrate remained crystalline, despite higher numbers of electrochemically inserted Li. Analysis of the differential charge plots also show different voltage dependent behavior, with a two-phase reaction mechanism observed in the K8LiδGe46-δ clathrate at a higher potential compared to the amorphization reaction observed in Ba8AlδGe46-δ. The drastically different electrochemical behavior in these Ge clathrates, both with type I structure, is not understood. The results are particularly interesting given that previous studies showed that K8LiδGe46-δ is composed of Li, Ge, and vacancies that form a heteroatom framework . This, along with our computational results on Ba8Li6Si40 with Li occupying framework sites point to a potentially important role of clathrate framework vacancies in the stabilization of the structure during electrochemical lithiation.

Summary: In summary, we must note that this project did not aim to build a "better battery", but rather sought to deepen our understanding of the relatively un-explored area of clathrate electrochemistry. The work carried out under the auspices of NSF explored the synthesis and phase stability range of lithiated clathrates using novel precursors. Also, for the first time, the electrochemical properties of Si and Ge clathrates were investigated. The derived clathrate structure-electrochemical property relationships yielded new knowledge that not only aids solid-state chemists in understanding the design rules for obtaining stable clathrate structures, but also creates new insights for battery scientists researching Li-based materials. We speculate that the same principles can be applied towards understanding the structural requirements for electrochemical insertion of Na+ into clathrates.
